metadata.case_name: Direct Recruits (Assistant Engineers) & State of Karnataka v. Promotees (Assistant Engineers)

facts.text: A new State came into existence on 1st November 1956 as a result of integration of areas from erstwhile States of Mysore, Madras, Coorg, Bombay and Hyderabad, named State of Mysore (later Karnataka).

In Public Works Departments of Merged States, there were non-gazetted officers below Assistant Engineers: Graduate Supervisors (Mysore), Junior Engineers (Madras), Supervisors (Hyderabad and Bombay). Graduate Supervisors paid Rs. 225/- p.m., lower than Assistant Engineers.

Prior to 1st November 1956, some Graduate Supervisors given charge of sub-divisions as Sub Divisional Officers; claimed equation with Assistant Engineers post-merger, initially turned down by Central Government.
Mysore Government Servants (Probation) Rules, 1957 promulgated on 6th February 1958; Mysore Government Servants (Seniority) Rules, 1957 came into force next day, both under Article 309.
Karnataka Public Service Commission invited applications for direct recruitment to Assistant Engineers on 1st October 1958.

On 15th November 1958, Karnataka Government promoted 167 as officiating Assistant Engineers (including 107 Graduate Supervisors from Mysore), notified 20th November 1958 (Exhibit A): promotions subject to review after finalisation of inter-se seniority of Supervisors and Cadre/Recruitment Rules; Sl. No. 74-167 purely temporary pending direct recruitment.
299 more from same class promoted to Assistant Engineers by notifications from 22nd December 1958 to 13th October 1960.

On 21st/31st August 1960, order for 107 Graduate Supervisors from Mysore: treated as Assistant Engineers, paid specific scales from 1st November 1956; placed below Assistant Engineers in inter-se seniority.

Mysore Public Works Engineering Department Services (Recruitment) Rules, 1960 promulgated 3rd December 1960: 40% direct recruitment, 50% promotion from Junior Engineers, 10% from Supervisors; cadre 344 permanent + 345 temporary posts.
Recruitment Rules amended 23rd October 1961, operative retrospectively from 1st March 1958.
88 candidates appointed as Probationary Assistant Engineers by direct recruitment on 31st October 1961.

Two notifications 27th February 1962: 231 Junior Engineers given regular promotions as Assistant Engineers from dates 15th November 1958 to 10th November 1960, subject to review after inter-se seniority of Junior Engineers; others deemed temporarily promoted on provisional basis.
6th October 1962, order (Exhibit D) superseding 31st August 1960 order: promoting 107 officers as Assistant Engineers from 1st November 1956.
By 24th September 1966, 85 direct recruits completed probation satisfactorily, absorbed substantively from 1st November 1962.
In 1971, orders promoting some direct recruits to Executive Engineers challenged by promotees in writ petition 15th September 1971.
28th September 1972, seniority list (Exhibit G) of Assistant Engineers as on 1st November 1959 prepared; promotees satisfied.
4th September 1973, new seniority list as on 1st January 1973 framed per Recruitment Rules; objections invited.
During 1973, more writ petitions by promotees challenging promotion of direct recruits to Executive Engineers.

Karnataka High Court judgment 30th November 1976 in various W.P.s: accepted promotees' claims - regular promotions to substantive posts prior to direct recruits; quota rule not applicable to pre-1st March 1958 promotees; direct recruits not subject to quota.

legal_issues.text: Whether promotees were appointed substantively as Assistant Engineers prior to direct recruits on 31st October 1961, determining their seniority per Seniority Rules.
Whether quota rule in Recruitment Rules applies to promotees appointed prior to 1st March 1958 and to direct recruits.
Scope of writ petitions: whether challenge to 4th September 1973 seniority list could be entertained.

petitioner_arguments.text: Scope of writ petitions limited to promotion to Executive Engineers, no challenge to 4th September 1973 seniority list.
Promotees' appointments were officiating/temporary, not substantive; direct recruits appointed substantively in clear vacancies, hence senior per Seniority Rules rule 2(a).
Regularisation does not confer permanence or substantive status retrospectively; cannot override rules under Article 309.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of Mysore v. S.V. Narayanappa; R. Nanjundappa v. T. Thimmiah

respondent_arguments.text: Promoted regularly/substantively prior to direct recruits, especially 107 from 1st November 1956; quota rule not applicable pre-1st March 1958.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Prakash Khanna v. S.A.F. Abbas; V.B. Badami v. State of Mysore

respondent_arguments.text: Direct recruits' appointments valid but outside quota as process started before rules.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: B. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore

court_reasoning.text: Scope of writs includes inherent challenge to seniority list as integral to claim of substantive prior promotion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Attack on seniority inherent in promotees' case.

court_reasoning.text: Direct recruits appointed substantively on probation in clear vacancies per Seniority Rules clause (a).
Promotees' appointments officiating/temporary until 31st October 1961; notifications specify officiating, temporary, subject to review.
Regularisation cures procedural defects, not confer permanence; cannot override Article 309 rules via Article 162 executive power.
Promotees rank junior to direct recruits; does not affect pre-1956 substantive holders or pre-rules substantive promotees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decide per Seniority Rules; first fill pre-existing substantives.

court_reasoning.text: Quota not applicable first time filling cadre per amendment proviso.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso to Recruitment Rules amendment applies.

holdings.text: Promotees held non-substantive appointments (officiating/temporary) prior to direct recruits; direct recruits senior per Seniority Rules.
Regularisation does not confer substantive/permanent status retrospectively or override rules.
Seniority per Seniority Rules; accommodate pre-1956/ pre-rules substantives first; quota proviso applies for first filling.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Prakash Khanna v. S.A.F. Abbas
precedents_cited.relevance: Basis for HC holding promotees regularly promoted substantively.

precedents_cited.case_name: V.B. Badami v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Quota rule not affect pre-1st March 1958 promotees (HC reliance).

precedents_cited.case_name: B. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Direct recruits' appointments valid outside rules as process pre-rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Mysore v. S.V. Narayanappa

precedents_cited.relevance: Regularisation cures procedure, not confer permanence; cannot override rules.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Rules framed under 309; executive power under 162 cannot override.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Government Servants (Probation) Rules, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines probationer as appointed on trial in substantive vacancy.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Government Servants (Seniority) Rules, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Seniority: substantive in clear vacancy senior to officiating/temporary.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Public Works Engineering Department Services (Recruitment) Rules, 1960
sections: Quota: 40% direct, 50% JE promotion, 10% Supervisors; amended 23-10-1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Recruitment quotas; amendment proviso not applicable first direct recruitment.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court accepted the appeals filed by direct recruits and State, set aside Karnataka High Court judgment dated 30-11-1976, held promotees not substantively appointed prior to direct recruits, directed seniority per Seniority Rules after accommodating pre-existing substantives, and implementation of Recruitment Rules from 1-3-1958.
outcome.relief_granted: Direct recruits senior to promotees; decide seniority and promotions accordingly.

key_quotes.text: "Officers appointed substantively in clear vacancies shall be senior to all persons appointed on officiating or any other basis in the same cadre."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to Seniority Rules determining direct recruits' superiority.

key_quotes.text: Regularisation does not connote permanence; cures procedural irregularities only.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects promotees' claim of retrospective substantive status.

key_quotes.text: "Ratification or regularisation is possible of an act which is within the power... but there has been some non-compliance with procedure."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Nanjundappa, limits effect of regularisation orders.
